title: poohsticks bridge saved nation earl buys 131000
story: AA Milne’s Poohsticks Bridge has been saved for the nation after the 11th Earl De La Warr bought it for £131,000.Milne and his son, Christopher Robin, invented the game on the bridge in Ashdown Forest, East Sussex. The bridge was dismantled in 1999 after visits by Winnie-the-Pooh enthusiasts caused too much wear and tear.The wooden planks lay behind a shed for years until two enterprising locals made an offer to the council, reconstructed the bridge – with missing pieces replaced by local oak – and put it up for auction.There were fears that Pooh’s global appeal would lead to the bridge being sold abroad. But Lord De La Warr lodged the winning bid, which was more than double the pre-sale estimate.Lord De La Warr owns the 2,000-acre Buckhurst Park estate, which includes an area that inspired Milne’s “100 Acre Wood”. However, he does not own the land on which Disney’s Poohsticks Bridge sits because it was sold off by his great-grandfather a century ago.Now, Lord De La Warr will be able to erect his bridge a short distance away from Disney’s replica. He can claim close links to the Winnie-the-Pooh story, as his father was a childhood friend of Christopher Milne and they played together in the woods.He said: “I am delighted to have been able to purchase the original bridge.“It will take pride of place on the estate, close to its original position, and I hope that many children (and adults) will be able to admire the original bridge which inspired one of the most famous games still played by children in the UK and abroad – Poohsticks.”Lord De La Warr told The  that more than a dozen bidders vied for the bridge. “I had set myself a limit and then I sort of had a feeling that probably it wasn’t quite enough, so I slightly upped it,” he said.“I didn’t like the idea of it going to America and if I hadn’t bought it, it would have gone abroad. I thought it should stay close to home.”Lord De La Warr plans to put the bridge over a stream in the 100 Acre Wood or close to The Dorset Arms pub in Withyham, which he also owns.James Rylands, a specialist in charge of the sale at Summers Place Auctions, said: “We were thrilled by the interest the bridge received globally, but are pleased that the bridge will stay in this country.”The seller, Mike Westphal, said the bridge had been “just dumped in a pile in the forest, under a sheet” when he bought it.He said: “Someone had to do something with it, and unfortunately that fell to me. It’s such an iconic item. It’s so many people’s childhoods.”More from Newspolitan Police worst force for solving sexual and violent crimeIn Liz Truss, Boris may have created a force more powerful than he realises‘I am not perfect’ says Insulate Britain protester after photos emerge of 10,000-mile holidayProtesters destroy pro-life stand at Oxford University freshers’ fairMedical student used fat suit to disguise himself as woman and attack ex-girlfriend with acidYou must know how to be impartial, BBC tells applicants for top news jobMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: prince andrew share strong family values says duchess york
story: The Duchess of York has described her pride in the “strong family values” and unity she shares with Prince Andrew.The Duchess, 61, took to the stage at the Henley Literary Festival, where she was promoting her Mills &amp Boon novel Her Heart for a Compass.While questions were carefully vetted in advance to avoid any awkward focus on the Royal family or her former husband’s sexual abuse lawsuit, she spoke warmly of her two new grandchildren, August and Sienna, both born this year, and the immense pride she has in her daughters, Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie.Told that actress Emma Laird Craig would play her in the next series of The Crown, the Duchess exclaimed “poor lady!” and laughed as she queried whether the actress had red hair and wished her luck.Asked if she had any advice for the actress, she said: “Just do the best job she can. To be cast in The Crown  ... a very successful TV show, how fabulous!”The Duchess revealed she was already halfway through her second Mills &amp Boon novel, with co-author Marguerite Kaye, which is called A Discerning Lady.She promised that it was “more of a sweeping romance” and that there would be “more bodice ripping” than in their first effort, which was published in August.On her daughters and their newborn babies, the Duchess said: “We all three of us keep our feet well on the ground. Both Prince Andrew and I feel very, very lucky.“We have strong family values and these two little naughties are phenomenal enhancers of an already unified family.Asked what kind of advice she gave Beatrice and Eugenie, she said: “When you go out of the front door, if you don't smile then don't go out of your front door.“Nobody wants to see a bad tempered princess. The pavement is a public place.”She added: “Humility is the finest thing you can ever have… to always remember where you have come from, who you are. Face your fears, be kind.I really strongly believe in no judgment, just getting on, and it too shall pass.In an apparent swipe at those online who have judged the Duke – with whom she still lives in Windsor – and his daughters, she criticised keyboard warriors”, adding: “Just stop it, get on, be joyous, be loving and be compassionate.”The Duchess, who has written many children’s books, including the successful Little Red and Budgie the Little Helicopter series, joked that hers would be the first books she read to her grandchildren.She revealed that August, Princess Eugenie’s son who was born in February, found her hysterically funny and laughed whenever she walked into the room.She also admitted that she could not wait for Sienna, born to Princess Beatrice last month, to read her novel, saying that she hoped she would know to stay strong and true to her beliefs.The Duchess also touched upon her own insecurities, admitting that 35 years in the public eye had occasionally left her wondering “how does the show go on?”She said: “I used to be so frightened of speaking openly about myself because of the fear about what other people would say.“This book is about really loving yourself, putting your oxygen mask on before helping another. I certainly did it myself.The Duchess admitted that she had no real idea how to write such a novel but that she and Kaye had learnt together. Kaye said: “If the phone pings at 4am chances are it’s going to be Sarah with an idea.”More from Newspolitan Police worst force for solving sexual and violent crimeIn Liz Truss, Boris may have created a force more powerful than he realises‘I am not perfect’ says Insulate Britain protester after photos emerge of 10,000-mile holidayProtesters destroy pro-life stand at Oxford University freshers’ fairMedical student used fat suit to disguise himself as woman and attack ex-girlfriend with acidYou must know how to be impartial, BBC tells applicants for top news jobMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: red list slashed just seven countries
story: Forty-seven countries have been removed from the Government’s red list in one of the biggest reopenings of foreign travel since the start of the pandemic.Only seven countries will remain on the list which requires travellers to be quarantined in a hotel on their return to the UK at a cost of £2,285 per person.Ministers also abandoned plans to force holidaymakers to video themselves taking tests after a backlash from the travel industry, which argued that it would be costly and a logistical nightmare for families.The Government is confident that the more expensive PCR tests will be scrapped in time for October half term, with families allowed to use cheaper lateral flow tests when they return to the UK.Grant Shapps, the Transport Secretary, said: “With half-term and winter sun around the corner, we’re making it easier for families and loved ones to reunite, by significantly cutting the number of destinations on the red list, thanks in part to the increased vaccination efforts around the globe.”Winter sun destinations including Mexico, South Africa, Thailand, Seychelles, Cape Verde, Costa Rica, Brazil and Bali in Indonesia will be removed from the red list at 4am on Monday, as will popular safari resorts in Tanzania, Botswana and Namibia.The seven countries remaining on the red list are Colombia, Peru, Ecuador, Panama, Haiti, Venezuela and the Dominican Republic.Nine of the 47 countries, including Argentina and Uruguay, remain closed to Britons unless they have exceptional reasons to travel to them. There are also growing fears the US will maintain its ban on British holidaymakers until Thanksgiving at the end of November.Mr Shapps succeeded in killing off Department of Health proposals for fully jabbed travellers to video themselves taking lateral flow tests while supervised by a health adviser from a private firm.Holidaymakers will now only be required to send a picture of their test kit result, possibly with ID such as a passport.Travellers will have to book their tests before flying, as happens now with PCRs, and include the test kit number on the passenger locator forms which allow people into the UK.The Department of Health and Social Care will be responsible for getting the new testing system in place by the start of the half term on Oct 23.  Sources said it would be ready by the time families started to return at the end of October at the latest.Sajid Javid, the Health Secretary, said: “Our robust border measures have helped protect the phenomenal progress of our vaccination programme, and it is because of this success both here and around the world that we can safely open up travel further and we can visit friends and family abroad.“We’re now making it easier and cheaper for people to travel by allowing fully vaccinated travellers from non-red list countries to use lateral flow tests on day two of arrival, as long as they provide proof of use.”The Government also announced it would recognise vaccines for arrivals from a further 37 countries and territories including Brazil, Ghana, Hong Kong, India, Pakistan, South Africa and Turkey.The decision means fully vaccinated people entering England from these locations will be exempt from quarantine, the pre-departure test and the day-eight post-arrival test.Only unvaccinated travellers now have to take a pre-departure test and then quarantine for 10 days on their return and pay for PCR tests on days two and eight of their return. The pre-departure test for double jabbed travellers was ditched on Oct 4.The latest moves follow the Foreign Office lifting its “ban” on non-essential travel to 32 countries including Fiji, Malaysia and Bangladesh. This ends the anomaly where its advice is out of kilter with the transport department’s travel lists.More from Newspolitan Police worst force for solving sexual and violent crimeIn Liz Truss, Boris may have created a force more powerful than he realises‘I am not perfect’ says Insulate Britain protester after photos emerge of 10,000-mile holidayProtesters destroy pro-life stand at Oxford University freshers’ fairMedical student used fat suit to disguise himself as woman and attack ex-girlfriend with acidYou must know how to be impartial, BBC tells applicants for top news jobMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sinister social media silencing dissent claims downton abbey
story: Social media has a sinister effect on public discourse by demonising anyone who holds an alternative opinion, Julian Fellowes has claimed.The creator of Downton Abbey said cancel culture was contributing to a prescriptive society in which dissent was no longer allowed, particularly among the younger generation.Social media has provided you with an audience, quite a numerous audience, who all agree with you. And that creates the sense that anyone who disagrees is being unbelievably unreasonable and needs to be silenced, he said. I find it quite sinister. We have to regain the ability to be disagreed with.He was speaking on the It's All Relative podcast which is hosted by Dr Eliza Filby, a historian who interviews two generations of a family. He appeared alongside his niece, the writer Jessica Fellowes.I find this tremendously prescriptive society we're living through at the moment rather naive, Julian Fellowes added. Every generation believes different things. Some of the things some generations believe seem wrong to us. Some of them are just bewildering.But the idea that we should judge them because they didn't believe the same things we believe… I think is naive.On issues such as climate change and ersity, Fellowes said: What I feel very strongly about this generation is that they allow all their views to be dictated. And I wish they would come up with some original views.He also said it was wrong to cancel people for things they had said many years ago. Most recently, England cricketer Ollie Robinson, 27, was suspended from international cricket over a series of racist and sexist tweets he had posted when aged 18 and 19.In 2015, Fellowes referred to the young as this great excuse generation, where nothing's ever your own fault and everything's always because someone was terrible to you.But he told the podcast that he now felt sympathy towards students because they had suffered due to the pandemic, saying: I think what they’ve gone through in the last 18 months has been extremely difficult, particularly the school and university generation who have essentially missed out on the experience.And I don't know what compensatory measures can be taken now, but I doubt very much they will be fully compensated for what they've missed.More from Newspolitan Police worst force for solving sexual and violent crimeIn Liz Truss, Boris may have created a force more powerful than he realises‘I am not perfect’ says Insulate Britain protester after photos emerge of 10,000-mile holidayProtesters destroy pro-life stand at Oxford University freshers’ fairMedical student used fat suit to disguise himself as woman and attack ex-girlfriend with acidYou must know how to be impartial, BBC tells applicants for top news jobMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: whisper children like living parents
story: The Spanish government wants to pay young adults to stop living with their parents. The average Spaniard doesn’t leave the family home until the age of 30. So Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez is proposing a new £250 monthly voucher for 18-35-year-olds, to encourage them to rent their own homes.Although British children leave home earlier than most Europeans (24, on average) we, too, are slowing down. Around 3.5 million young adults in the UK now live with their parents, an increase of a third in a decade. This is generally thought to be a bad thing, caused by exorbitant housing costs.But what if there’s more to it than just economics? What if children are staying at home because – whisper it – they actually like living with their parents?It’s not impossible, the way it once was. Previous generations of parent were almost ideologically opposed to getting chummy with their children. The sons of the ruling classes were systematically removed from the home at seven, lest they should grow too attached to their mothers. Separation was thought to be character-building. Even in the most loving families, the ide between young and old was clearly demarcated by authority – the absolute rule of the parents.Since the Sixties, each generation of parents has further loosened its collar. Rules of intergenerational decorum that once seemed cast iron have been bent, and then broken, and then tossed aside. My own parents, though exceedingly relaxed and bonhomous for their time, drew the line at letting boys stay over. When I was 21, a boyfriend hitchhiked all the way from Newcastle to London to see me. “How wonderful!” said my dad, ushering him in. “We’d better put a tent up in the garden.”My cohort of parents has largely jettisoned that rule. Indeed, the traditional cry of “My house, my rules” seems to be fading out altogether. Children are increasingly treated as equals – albeit truculent and ignorant equals – whose voices should be heard.The results of this experiment are mixed: no one could claim that the nation’s children appear much happier or more well-behaved for it. But they do seem to enjoy the company of their parents – and vice versa. Several surveys have found that, despite the stresses of lockdown, most families have relished spending more time together since the pandemic began.Far from being a sign of failure, living with your parents denotes a kind of success. After centuries of struggle, families may finally be learning to get along.Uniquely among the human race, I have never watched The Sopranos. I’m sure it’s as good as everyone says, but I find our cultural fascination with the mafia irksome. I can’t buy into the idea of violent thugs being brilliant strategists, or full of hidden depths.Sure enough, the reality is gratifyingly stupid. Court papers filed in New York reveal that members of the Colombo crime family have been conducting extortion rackets by text message, leaving a juicy digital trail for detectives. According to one former mobster, it’s a generational problem: “Everything is on the phones with them!” But one of the texts – “Hey, this is the 2nd text, there isn’t going to be a 3rd” – was sent by a 56-year-old knuckle-dragger. The idiocy goes back generations only the technology is new.More from Newspolitan Police worst force for solving sexual and violent crimeIn Liz Truss, Boris may have created a force more powerful than he realises‘I am not perfect’ says Insulate Britain protester after photos emerge of 10,000-mile holidayProtesters destroy pro-life stand at Oxford University freshers’ fairMedical student used fat suit to disguise himself as woman and attack ex-girlfriend with acidYou must know how to be impartial, BBC tells applicants for top news jobMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: bumbling boris proves covid greek
story: :root Bumbling Boris proves Covid is all Greek to him in orgy of self-congratulationPaul Routledge has ed from holidaying in Greece to take in the Tory conference in all its non-mask wearing glory as Johnson claims to have the guts to change Britain while showing he hasn’t even got the guts to face up to the continuing Covid crisisBraggadocio Boris Johnson - no mask, no clue Image: Getty ImagesopinionByPaul Routledge:,  Oct | commentsIt was “don’t mention the C-word” at the Tory conference in Manchester. Ministers avoided all talk of Covid, until braggadocio Boris Johnson played it for laughs in an orgy of self-congratulation. He joked about Michael Gove dancing in a nightclub, and applauded himself for their “cheek by jowler” gathering.Unlike Labour’s bash last week, the Tories didn’t wear face masks, or observe social distancing. No virus testing.I’m just back from Greece, where the infection rate is around  per ,. Here in Sutton and Cross Hills, the most recent figure was , making me three times more likely to catch it at home. But face coverings are mandatory on Greek public transport, in shops and public buildings. Hotel guests must wear plastic gloves to collect food for breakfast. Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  You must show a Covid passport to enter even an open-air museum, and many people – particularly oldies – wear masks in the street. What a dference! Blasé BoJo bellowed on the radio: “There is nothing I can see in the data, nothing I can see in rates of infection at the moment that makes me think we need to drop Plan A. It justies the decision to open up.”  This latter-day Admiral Nelson can’t see that new infections regularly exceed , a day, putting the UK at or near the top of the world league – that Covid features in one in  deaths registered, amounting to  in one September week. We now lag behind Portugal, Spain, France and Italy in the vaccination league. Johnson boasts he has the guts to change Britain. He hasn’t even got the guts to face up to the continuing Covid crisis. Grave situation Killjoys in Stockton-on-Tees, County Durham, protested about a beer festival in their local church, St Mary the Virgin, that spilled over into the graveyard. Organiser, Rev Martin Anderson, raising funds for the church clock, apologised profusely for pints on the tombs.  I fail to see why. Churchyard revelry was normal for centuries from the Middle Ages, with special “church ale” brewed by the wardens. If I qualy for burial in Cowling churchyard, I shan’t mind people quaffing real ale round it. Just no dancing on the grave, please. Toxic type of scroll model Oh, how I chuckled when social media addicts bewailed the six-hour shutdown of Facebook. They came on the airwaves to express grief at being cut off from their communications drug. There is one sure way of getting this monkey off their back. Just say No. Facebook has been with us for only  years, its subsidiary profit-making s Instagram and WhatsApp for even fewer.  Before that, we got by with email, the phone, the letter and that most rewarding form of communication of all, conversation. Between real people, face to face. Why should we now put ourselves in thrall to the multi-billionaire Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg  And put young people at risk of addiction to this toxic drug  I have nothing to do with social media – any of it – and I don’t feel my le is inadequate. Try it some time. Welsh dino A new Welsh dinosaur has been discovered, with rows of sharp teeth to tear the flesh off its victims. For understandable reasons, it has not been named Tyrannosaurus Drakefordius. story: :root Labour MP Neil Coyle opens up about mental health struggle following Jo Coxs murderThe -year-old - who had a brick hurled through his bedroom window during parliaments Brexit wars - also spoke about his turbulent childhood Image: PAByRachel Wearmouth:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Labour MP Neil Coyle has opened up about his mental health battles after a brick was hurled through his bedroom window at the height of parliamentaposs Brexit wars.Speaking to GB Newsapos Gloria de Piero, the MP for Bermondsey and Southwark revealed the tidal wave of stress he experienced during the high-pressure period, which came in the wake of the murder of fellow MP Jo Cox and amid Labouraposs own factional warfare. During the wide-ranging interview, the -year-old father-of-one also opened up about his turbulent childhood, which almost included him and his siblings being taken into care after mum Mary was diagnosed with schizophrenia. The MP said he has faced mental health struggle which only became clear to him when a local councillor urged him to seek support. He said: It was an important moment, actually, because I thought, this is visible to other people. Iaposm clearly not happy. My Coyle said he appeared to be completely ing and was out and about in parliament, but the atmosphere in Westminster was febrile as the aftermath of the Brexit vote played out.  Things came to a head when his home, which he shares with his we and young daughter Esme, was targeted. He said: I had somebody break the window, my home, my bedroom window home during the Brexit debate. He added: There’s no way out the back, it’s a brick wall. So, I was sat with a cricket bat in case they came through. The MP said he needed help from therapists in the weeks and months ahead as the massive stress took a toll. He said: Iaposve had bouts of depression and things, but I have CBT . I think that when Jo was murdered, it triggered lots... that was a very dficult time. Mr Coyle, who grew up in Luton alongside two brothers and a sister, said his childhood was very dficult but, in the end, helped him to build emotional resilience.  He said his motheraposs mental health deteriorated when his father left. He said: Sadly, some of my earliest memories are the most dficult. There was a time where mum set fire to the living room carpet because she was trying to keep us warm. There was no intent to damage or harm anybody or the property. We used to have the coin meter. People donapost see them anymore, so they find it hard to understand - but I donapost know whether she didnapost have any money to work the heating system. I donapost know whether her mental health had collapsed so badly that she just didnapost know how to do it - but she set fire to the carpet. title: school pupils could told wear
story: :root School pupils could be told to wear face masks again this winterCovid surgesEducation Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said he did not want ato the bubble system in England - but accepted compulsory face coverings in class could make a comebackStudents in a classroom last year Image: PAByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Oct | commentsSecondary school pupils could be told to wear face-masks in school once again to keep Covid at bay this winter, the Education Secretary has admitted. Nadhim Zahawi said he did not want to see theof bubbles where whole classes or year groups were sent home after a positive test. But he admitted that compulsory face-masks in lessons could make a come-backcases spike.Iaposve got a contingency plan, as you would expect me to do. It contains lots of contingencies, including masks, absolutely, he told Sky News.The mandatory wearing of face coverings in schools and colleges was scrapped in May, but Government guidance says that directors of public health could advise schools to reintroduce themcases spike.It comes after Government figures showed the number of children out of school for Covid- related reasons in England increased by two thirds in a fortnight. The DfE estimates that .% of all pupils - more than , children - were not in class for reasons connected to coronavirus on Thursday last week.This is up from , children, or .% of all pupils, on September  - a % rise from two weeks ago.Mr Zahawi also defended the slow rollout of carbon dioxide monitors which were first promised by the Department for Education in August.In Wales, secondary school and college pupils will be advised to take daily lateral flow tests for seven dayssomeone in their household tests positive for coronavirus, the Welsh Government has announced. Speaking to Sky News, Mr Zahawi said he was concerned about the impact Covid- measures had on attendance. He said: The good news is that - and thanks to the brilliant teachers and support staff and parents and children - % of schools are open. Attendance has gone up, the last set of figures I looked at was about %, which obviously will fluctuate depending on infection rates. But my priority is to protect education, keep those schools open. But he said he was not looking toto the bubble system to do so, because actually, you saw the fall off in attendance which really does harm mental wellbeing, mental health of children. That is despite Englnad’s schools previously being told backup plans must “cover the possibility that in some local areas it may become necessary to reintroduce ‘bubbles’ for a temporary period, to reduce mixing between groups. “Any decision to recommend the reintroduction of ‘bubbles’ would not be taken lightly and would need to take account of the detrimental impact they can have on the delivery of education.” Comment MORE ON Coronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: :root Woman who didnt know she was pregnant gives birth  minutes after getting stomach acheTilda Kantala, from Turku, Finland, had regular periods and didnt experience any sickness while pregnant, but while on summer holiday with her family, her little one arrived in styleTilda had no idea she was nine months pregnant Image: Jam PressByLaura AbernethyJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct | commentsA mum who woke up with a tummy ache thinking sheaposd eaten something dodgy got the shock of her le eight minutes later when she gave birth to a surprise baby. Tilda Kantala, , from Turku, Finland, had no idea she was pregnant when she woke up on June  and felt a small burning pain - but soon realised what was happening. “I thought it was just from eating something bad or something that my stomach can’t handle,” the young mum said. “It wasn’t like normal contractions but then came a very familiar feeling - the urge to push. “That’s when I figured out that I was in labour and about to give birth to a baby or babies. At that point, I didn’t know anything.”For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Tilda, who also has a two-year-old daughter Aleia, said her periods were normal throughout the pregnancy and she didnapost experience any sickness. She said she had gained a bit of weight but thought it was just normal weight fluctuation. It wasnapost until the night she gave birth in a summer cottage sheaposd visited with her family that she realised something was wrong. She said: “I had just woken up and my mother and sister and my daughter were outside already. “At the last minute, I was able to shout ‘Mum’ because I heard her coming into the house to get something.  “She came into my room and saw me in pain and about to push for the first time. She asked: ‘ARE YOU PREGNANT! ’ and I answered: ‘I guess so.’ By the time her mum had run into the room, the babyaposs head was already crowning. Tilda recalls her mum askingshe could wait to push, but there was no way she could delay any longer. My mum went to get some towels and get some more help from my uncle, who called the ambulance. While he was on the call, I pushed three times and the baby was out, she said. When the ambulance arrived, baby Alec had already been born. He and Tilda were taken to hospital to be checked over as Tilda hadnapost had any scans or tests throughout the pregnancy.  “I was confused, scared, anxious. I was alone already, a single mother for my daughter and now another one was coming into our lives, she said. “Luckily, the baby was perfectly fine and healthy.” While in hospital, Tilda started to organise what she could and her family helped prepare for them coming home. She needed to find a new car seat for the baby, as well as a double pram to take both kids out and about. “It was pretty dficult to buy everything in such a hurry but I managed it pretty well in my opinion and I’m lucky to have my parents and other relatives help with buying everything, she said. Four days later, Tilda was allowed to take Alec home from hospital. Heaposs now three months old and thriving. Tilda says after she got over the initial shock, she has embraced being a mum to two little ones. She said: “I came to terms with what had happened. It took a few weeks but I’m fine with it now. story: :root Bridesmaid drops  stone in huge transformation after hating wedding photosBeing in and seeing the wedding pictures had a “huge effect” on Natalia Georgis confidence and prevented her from enjoying the experience as much as she would have liked to.Natalia Georgis, from Hayes, London, weighed st lb Image: Natalia Georgis   CATERS NEWSByJoseph Broady:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA bridesmaid who struggled seeing herself in photos from the big day dropped  stone after deciding enough was enough. Natalia Georgis, from Hayes, London, weighed st lb when she put on a bridesmaid dress in May , the largest size the shop had, which had also been altered to fit her. Seeing the pictures had a “huge effect” on her confidence, she said, and how she had felt in the dress prevented her from enjoying the experience as much as she would have liked to. It was from that moment that I knew I wanted to make a change and start to lose some of the weight,” Natalia said. She began researching options to start her weight loss journey and decided to fork out £, - with the help of her family - to undergo a gastric sleeve fitting later that year in a bid to shrink her frame. Two weeks prior to the fitting, I had to only drink milk and was allowed one stock cube a day to keep my levels up,” she said. And after the fitting, she was only able to eat soups and soft foods. Natalia, who now weighs st lbs and is a size , was also told that the gastric sleeve would only help her lose part of her weight - the majority of her results would come from her own hard work.  For two months I was not able to do any form of exercise after the fitting which was incredibly frustrating,” she recalled. “Once the two month mark had cleared, I was in the gym four times a week working hard on my cardio, and when the lockdown came about, I would do home workouts. Even when I was not feeling up to going, I would push myself because I would be reminded of what I was working for. Natalia was also motivated by the positive comments of friends and family around her on her journey. She said: There was nothing more encouraging than somebody saying that I looked really good lately and askingI had lost weight. The confidence boost it gave me, combined with the results of my hard work at the gym showing on the scales was incredible. Natalia also changed her diet entirely in order to work with her new active lestyle. She said one of the best things about her journey was discovering how much she enjoyed cooking. Whereas before I would jump for an early option like a takeaway Chinese or a curry, I am now buying all of my ingredients fresh and cooking at home. I still eat three meals a day, but I am now far more conscious of healthier options and alternatives to what I was eating before. It has also had an incredibly positive affect on her mental health, as her concern about being judged for weight was gone. Now, I can hold a conversation with anyone and go out feeling like my confidence has never been higher,” she said. As a result of her incredible weight loss, Natalia was left with loose skin, which she has been treated for at Highgate Private Hospital in London. She added: I have to have three rounds of surgery costing a total of £, in order to remove the excess skin and have currently had two so far.” The initial surgery was “quite traumatic”, she said, especially as she had to go back into surgery after her first procedure in order to correct an internal bleed. The second surgery was in September and was totally dferent, and I was up and walking around almost immediately afterwards which was brilliant.” Her third and final surgery is approaching in December. Natalia had managed to stay grounded despite receiving a lot of interest from men since her body transformation. I have had a lot of messages but in all honesty, I am in a great place right now and am happy,” she laughed. Natalia began sharing her journey online on TikTok, where she has an amazing .k followers, videos with over k likes, and receives messages from lots of people asking for advice. Before long, I was getting people reaching out and asking for tips and calling me an inspiration which was a real shock,” she said. I was just trying to be as honest as possible and send recipes and tips which worked for me to anyone who asked for my advice. title: expat familys lives ruined brexit
story: :root Exclusive: Cruise ship familys lives ruined by Brexit as rules mean they need dozens of visasCruise ship workers are being forced out of the profession and overlooked for their European Union counterparts who dont need work visas, a veteran of the industry has claimedJean Williams, here with her husband Glen, says Brexit is making working on cruise ships very hard for Brits Image: Jean WilliamsByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsCruise ship workers are leaving the industry in their droves due to crippling post-Brexit visa rules, a veteran of the industry has claimed. Jean Williams says her le is being aposdestroyedapos and the livelihoods of many of her friends apossacricedapos thanks to new employment rules. Her  year career working on the river boats of Europe has been in serious jeopardy since the UK officially left the EU at the beginning of . Now the -year-old, her husband, son and thousands like them must apply for inidual visas for each EU country they visit or sail through the waters of, as well as buy private health insurance. She calculates the total extra cost at almost £, a year, with the y visa application process taking up to eight weeks. As a result of the extra bureaucracy, many cruise firms are refusing to hire British workers, Jean says.For cruise workers are least, Prime Minister Boris Johnsonaposs promises that Brexit would be a aposbonfire of red tapeapos and would lead to aposhundreds of thousands of new jobsapos seem a far cry from reality.My husband and I did not want Brexit. We voted to remain but we are most definitely victims of Brexit, Jean, from Kent, told The Mirror. I do not remember Mr Johnson saying that the entertainment industry’s professions, livelihoods and lives would be sacriced when he was campaigning for Brexit over five years ago.  While I may not agree with the decision to leave the EU, I respect the outcome of Brexit. But I don’t deserve to be Brexit’s victim either. I am not a remoaner as we have been unfairly labelled, but because these issues were not sorted out properly before we left the EU, Brexit is destroying my le, the lives of my family, the lives of many people I know personally and thousands of people I will never know. For the first  years of Jean and husband Glenaposs careers as entertainers on cruise ships their work le was relatively simple.  As passport holders of an EU country they had the right to move and work in  other European nations with no need for a visa or health insurance. All of that changed when the UK officially left the bloc. If we visit ten countries, we have to get ten visas, Jean said. You have to apply for them at the embassies in London. You go for an appointment and you have an interview. It is a lot of paper work and thereaposs no guarantee youaposll get a visa. The visas cost about £ each. We are also talking health insurance which you never needed before. Thataposs £, a year for my husband and I. When the industry started to restart after the coronavirus pandemic, Jean discovered the new rules were having a big impact on her employment opportunities.She continued: I started to notice that the adverts advertising the positions us Brits have been doing for decades, were now saying aposEU passport holders onlyapos. Agencies told me they wonapost employ us when I called them. To put this into perspective, we are actually talking about hundreds of thousands of UK jobs and lives being effected here. UK workers including the self employed, cruise directors, entertainers, musicians, dancers, speciality acts, bar staff, chefs, waiters, cleaners, sound crew, lighting crew, hairdressers, makeup artistsare all going to lose work to European Workers unless an agreement is made between the UK and the EU to enable us all to continue to work in Europe. Many of these people effected are young people who are just starting out. Many have studied long and hard and got themselves into financial debt in order to be able to do the job of their dreams, only to find there are no jobs for them. Many of these peopleare very experienced in their chosen profession and have been working in the same industry for many years and this is how we are repaid for all our hard work over the years. Jean and Glen are determined to jump through the bureaucratic hoops and fork out the extra costs so they can continue working in the industry they love. Others, including two of the six couples they most recently worked on stage with, have already given up on cruise ship work or are in the process of doing so. My son and his girlfriend have been working for many years as a dance couple for a UK agent throughout Europe, only to be told this year their contract is cancelled as the agency can no longer work them anymore due to the EU restrictions and they are both devastated, Jean added. When asked whether the UK had plans to negotiate an EU wide work visa for British workers, a Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Officer simply said: Visa routes for other countries are a matter for those countries. compared staying at the property to aposliving at the bottom of a water slideapos. Kate Marlow, from Bridgend, Wales, said her home has flooded four times in less than two years, causing more than £, worth of damage. The -year-old said the problems started when Storm Dennis struck in February last year, WalesOnline reports. Water poured into the home, which she shares with her mum, brother and five dogs, ruining everything apart from the top floor.She said: We moved into our house in August  and all was fine until Storm Dennis arrived in early . All this water came running down the mountain road opposite and went right through the garage and into our home - the bottom two floors of which are technically below ground level because the house is built on a gradient.  She added that everything other than the top floor was ruined - furniture destroyed, ceilings put through - and the family were forced to move into temporary accommodation while the clean-up and repair work took place.Unfortunately, because of our dogs, the closest pet-friendly place we could find was in Barry - nearly  miles away - and the arrival of Covid restrictions meant we ended up stuck there for  months, she added. However, an initial council review deemed the incident a one-off, attributable to the freak conditions brought about by the storm.  But,  days later, the same thing happened again - and then for a third time in January . On that occasion Iaposd driven back from Barry to let the painters and decorators in, only to find inside was soaking wet, said Kate.And now itaposs happened for a fourth time following that awful weather we had earlier this week.That said, none of our neighbours ever seem to be affected - they canapost work out why it keeps happening and neither can we.  Bank worker Kate said her home is the only property on the road that is repeatedly hit by flood water whenever thereaposs heavy rainfall. Thereaposs just farm land above us, along with an old quarry from which any excess water would drain away in dferent directions, she said. Maybe somethingaposs changed to alter the route of that run-off, I just donapost know. Weaposve had a look around and none of the nearby culverts seem to be blocked or anything. And while our insurance company has been very good so far, thereaposs a limit to how often theyaposll be willing to pay out. I just canapost bear the idea of losing everything yet again. A spokesperson from Bridgend County Borough Council said, We have maintained contact with the residents at this address and visited the property as recently as this week. A great deal of work has been carried out to try and determine the source of the flooding. While it appears to occur during exceptionally heavy rainfall, the cause is not linked to the council-maintained drainage network.  He added that following investigations and discussions with local private landowners a scheme has been developed which would enable inlet headwalls - small retaining structures placed at the entrance of storm water pipes or culverts - to be improved on a nearby private road. story: :root Exclusive: Grandma, , left housebound for five years as BMI being too high for knee surgeryMargaret McDonald, from Anniesland, Glasgow, says she has has been housebound since  waiting to have knee replacement surgery but keeps being told her BMI is too high, in apparent contradiction to NHS guidelinesMargaret McDonald has been waiting for five years to have knee replacement surgery Image: Margaret McDonaldByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Oct | commentsA grandmother has been left housebound for five years as her BMI is marginally too high to have knee replacement surgery. Margaret McDonald has been waiting since  to have the op done and claims she was the same weight - around -and-a-half stone - when she had surgery seven years ago on her other knee. The -year-old, from Anniesland, Glasgow, has osteoarthritis and said the pain is so severe in her knee she was prescribed morphine doses similar to someone dying from cancer. Sheaposs been presented for surgery by her GP multiple times in five years but each time a pre-op assessment at the Scottish cityaposs Queen Elizabeth Hospital has led to her being told she is too heavy. And despite attending reduced mobility exercise classes designed for OAPs seeing her lose over a stone, Margaret was still told her body mass index needs to come down.Have you had a similar issue to Margaret  Let us know at webnews@mirror A spokesperson for NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde told the Mirror a BMI limit of  and under is a clinical requirement for this type of procedure. With Margaretaposs height of ftin, her BMI is around , meaning she just misses the cut off. NHS guidance also states while morbidly obese patients should not normally be listed for such an op, there can be exceptions when all reasonable attempts have been made to reduce weight and there are compelling circumstances. After doing her own research, Margaret said patients in similar circumstances have found some private orthopaedic surgeons will operate beyond the  threshold. She said each exercise class has left her bedridden for a day after due to knee inflammation, while a side-effect of the chronic depression medication she takes is weight gain. Margaretaposs psychiatrist has even been slowly reducing her dosage in an effort to help her sht the pounds - but she said losing a substantial amount in her condition is not possible. The grandmother-of-three said her le is like a permanent lockdown, and she even had to have her beloved dog Bruno re-homed because she couldnapost take him on walks.  I’ve lost my voluntary work that I used to do. I’ve lost doing things with my family, taking part in my grandkids’ activities. The impact it’s had on me has been incredible, she said. I’ve been presented for surgery three or four times but every time I was told no, BMI is too high. When you’re immobile and nothing much you can do regarding exercise what are you meant to do  I don’t just sit and eat my face off all day and not care about my weight. I just can’t sustain [any physical activities] because of pain and immobility. The impact on everyday le is just horrendous. Getting dressed, doing day-to-day things that you take for granted. Anytime I need anything I have to go online because I can’t even walk around the supermarket or go to a park, there’s nothing I can do. It’s like being in lockdown for five years. You’re just existing, that’s about it - it’s a horrible existence, she added. Margaretaposs daughter is her certied carer but has three young sons to look after as well and lives where. Prior to her mobility issues she said she was far more active and even taught first aid as a volunteer. She previously worked for the City of Glasgow College for  years and has been volunteering for the Scottish Police Authority, which she has been able to continue from home in the pandemic. An NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde spokesman said: While we cannot comment on inidual patients, a BMI limit of  and under is a clinical requirement for us to proceed with procedures of this nature. We have every sympathy with patients who may struggle with their weight and provide advice and support to help reduce weight before surgery. title: it doesnt feel like work
story: :root It doesn’t feel like work! - mum spices things up with surprising new careerAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Oct When it comes to decision making do you play it safe, or seek out fun and adventure  If you fancy yourself as a thrill seeker, then Zinger Popcorn is for you. To celebrate the launch of Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only - we decided to champion people who like to spice things up, including Hannah Murphy, . When she reached a career crossroads in , Hannah struck out on a new adventurous course, and almost a decade on has no regrets about her bold decision. When I was made redundant from my eight-year career as a flight attendant, flying both domestically and between the UK and Japan, I saw it as an opportunity set myself a new challenge, and have new adventures, says Hannah who lives in Southampton with her husband and three children, Angelina, , Archie,  and Adriana, five. At the time I was a single mum of one after my previous relationship ended, and the ‘sensible’ decision would have been to take a - desk job, something stable but didnapost challenge me. That’s just not me though, I have to love what I do and find joy in it every day. Instead, Hannah trained as a fitness instructor and began to incorporate a hula hoop into her training. It wasn’t just a useful exercise tool, great for toning and core strength, it was so much fun. The moment I started hula hooping, I was transported back to my childhood, it was really liberating. As word got out about Hannah’s hula hooping prowess, friends and family began to ask for lessons, followed by requests from local schools for Hannah to come in and teach children how to hula hoop.  It snowballed and before I knew it, I had so much interest in hula hooping fitness classes, I had to train other instructors to help me. I went on to create a training programme called Globe Fit and today I have teachers all around the world, from Australia to America, all teaching my programme. I love teaching hula hooping, particularly adults, because they might start off a bit self-conscious and inhibited but soon their inner child is released and they just go for it! I’ve taught people aged from teenagers to eighty-year-olds. Last year, I hosted the first ever world hula hooping championship, which will be taking place again later this year. After launching the UKaposs first hula hooping championship in , which took place in Fareham, Hampshire, Hannah decided to go global in . Not even a pandemic could stop her with the event going virtual and around twenty-five competitors, women and men of all ages and abilities, taking part from as far afield as India, America and Australia. I had a  of four judges, including John Parnell aka Hoop Guy who appeared on Britainaposs Got Talent in . Competitors submitted videos of themselves performing with their hoop, and were marked on everything from skill to tricks they could do, with the  judging the videos.  The second world championship will take place in December this year, again virtually, and I hope to have even more people taking part. It’s amazing to be a part of people experiencing something new and fun, it doesn’t feel like work! Hannah’s story is a great example of how le can get better when you try something new, soyou already love Popcorn chicken - tasty pops of  per cent chicken breast, perfect to nibble on by themselves or as a side - then itaposs time to turn up the heat. Popcorn Chicken Zinger is the same delicious chicken and moreish crunch, but KFC have pumped up the spice for those who can handle a kick. Make sure you get your hands on a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it’s only available until October .Download the app, head in store or order online. And according to Andrew Morton, the author behind the unauthorised biography Meghan: A Hollywood Princess, Meghan had to learn about the royals from Harry. Appearing on ITVaposs This Morning, he said : As she [Meghan] said herself, she didnapost read the tabloids, she didnapost watch TMZ. She learnt what she learnt about the Royal Family from Harry. title: sobbing four year old found
story: :root Sobbing four-year-old found wandering streets alone after walking out of schoolFrightened Alfie Summers was found crying in the rain in his PE kit after walking half-a-mile from St Richards CofE First School in Evesham, Worcester, after slipping out totally unnoticedKatrina Deegan is demanding to know how little Alfie could leave the premises unnoticed Image: Anita Maric   SWNSByEd ChattertonSam Elliott-GibbsCat Phillips:,  Oct | comments A livid mum is demanding answers to why her crying four-year-old son was found wandering the streets after being allowed to walk out of school totally unnoticed.Little Alfie Summers left class and strolled out though an unlocked gate before crossing several busy roads. Staff at St Richardaposs CofE First School in Evesham, Worcester, didnapost even realise he was missing. The frightened reception pupil was found crying for his mum and soaked to the bone wearing just his PE kit in the torrential rain. Police were called and officers phoned around and drove to several local nurseries with Alfie before eventually ing him to the right school.  Furious mum Katrina Deegan, , is now demanding to know how her boy managed to escape from under the noses of oblivious school staff. Full-time mum-of-four Katrina, of Hampton, Evesham, said: Itaposs every parentaposs worst nightmare and anything could have happened to him.  Iaposve had no answers from the school how this was allowed to happen. He could have been taken or he could have been seriously hurt. Apparently he was in a really distressed state and running back and forth across a busy road before a woman found him and called police. I dread to think that my little boy could have been taken from me all under the schools watch where your supposed to leave your child with confidence thinking they are safe. The school was alerted after a local resident called police after finding Alfie sobbing and calling out for his mum as he tried to walk the mile journey back to his home. Alfie told his mum he had decided to walk out because a teacher had been horrible and shouted at him. Katrina added: When I got the phone call from the headteacher I panicked and was full of dread - I thought I was never going to see Alfie again. He said there had been a aposlittle bit of an incidentapos and that Alfie had gone missing and the police were on the way with him.  When youaposre told by a school there has been an incident you expect him to have fallen in the playground and bumped his head - not that he had gone missing. When the police turned up Alfie was so upset and distraught. He was soaked to the bone and must have bene terried. The officers had to drive him around nurseries and schools because he was in his PE kit rather than unorm so didnapost know where he was supposed to be. I asked Alfie why he left the school and he said because a teacher was being horrible to him and he wanted to come home to me. Heaposs like any other child, heaposs not naughty and doesnapost run away, he is usually as good as gold. I am so grateful someone kind found him because I dread to think what could have happened.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. If he had walked for five minutes more he would have been on a busy main road and the street he walked up is busy enough with speeding drivers. I was sat at home oblivious thinking my son is safe at school while he was walking around scared in the pouring rain. Officers took him round the local nurseries to try and find out where he had come from as he was wearing his PE kit and they could not identy the school. Mark Ridlinton, head teacher at St Richardaposs CofE First School, has apologised and said they are reviewing their procedures as well as investigating the incident. He said: We are extremely sorry that a child went missing during school hours and we are very grateful for West Mercia Police for their support during this incident and that the child was found safe and well. We held a meeting with parents to discuss the incident and we are currently reviewing our procedures and investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident in detail. We will update all parents once our investigation is concluded and have begun taking action without delay on any issues identied. We have increased security on the front playground gate, and the front playground is no longer in use throughout the school day, whilst our investigations are carried out. We would like to apologise to the parents and the child for this unacceptable incident and assure all parents that we take our responsibilities extremely seriously and whilst in our care, pupil safety is our top priority. title: spooky 14th century pub home
story: :root Spooky th century pub home to mummied severed hand of a cheating gamblerThe hand at The Haunch of Venison, Salisbury, has been stolen not once, but twice - but is now securely locked in one of the pubs bars and the mummied hand, inset, Richard Hudd   Western Daily Press." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _escenic-.jpg" width"" "" The Haunch of Venisonand the mummied hand, inset, Richard Hudd   Western Daily Press.ByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Oct | commentsFrom knives standing on end to pints of ale smashing to the ground - a Salisbury pub is said to be the most haunted in the city, and is home to a bizarre relic. The Haunch of Venisonaposs history spans back  years, first recorded around , and is home to the mummied hand of a man whose spirit is said to haunt the boozer. The hand has hit headlines in previous years for being stolen not once, but twice, and has been secretly ed on both occasions. Many people have reported paranormal activity in the three-storey pub, including the owners themselves, who state so on the pub’s website.Former landlords and landladies have even seen the spirit of a man in a brown shirt and braces watching them sleep,Wiltshire Live reported .The th century building was originally used as a church house when St Thomas’ spire was being built, and is believed to have later been used as a brothel.  The boozer features three small bars, known as the Horsebox, Death Row and the House of Lords. Under a fireplace in the Haunch, a disused bread oven is home to a smoke preserved mummied hand, chopped from the arm of an th century gambler who got caught cheating at a game of cards - so the story goes. The pub is said to be haunted by the spirit of a ‘Demended Whist Player’ - a man who won a large sum of cash whilst playing cards in the s. As locals thought he was cheating, a butcher chopped off his hand, which is thought to be the mummied hand located in the bar.Wondering where to eat, drink or visit for your next UK holiday  At Chill we help you decide where to go and stay next with hundreds of recommendations right on your doorstep. Visit our brilliant new website chill and start packing. If youaposd also like weekly inspiration and advice for your next trip, you can sign up to the Chill newsletter here. For the latest must-have travel news follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter. The unusual relic was discovered when the Salisbury pub was renovated in . It was stolen from its display case in , but was secretly ed a few weeks later, before it was taken again in . The severed hand is now securely locked - but still attracts swaths of people to take a look at it. Pub punter Ruby Vitorino Moody spent six years writing a book documenting the Haunch’s many tales of the supernatural and its wider history, called The A-Z of the Haunch of Venison. As well as the hauntings, the Horsebox bar is said to have hosted Winston Churchill and Dwight Eisenhower, where they apparently discussed preparations for the D-Day landings.  Recommended by the CAMRA Good Pub Guide for  years running, the Haunch of Venison is home to several interesting and historical features, such as tiles from Salisbury Cathedral purchased in the s for just £, as well as a pewter top bar - one of just six in the whole country. Owners of the pub said: “There is a rare wooden carved elevated arch with seven origin gravity-fed spirit taps fitted in . According to CAMRA there are only five of them left in the United Kingdom. “There are no dispensers on the counter and hand pumps are affixed to the bar back-fitting, which also has drawers - very rare as well.” Comment MORE ON ChillCampaign for Real AleSalisbury, Wiltshire" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman drove wrong way down
story: :root Woman drove wrong way down motorway and killed headteacher in head-on smashAnn Marie Crooks Renault Clio hit the vehicle of Paula Kingdon moments after she had narrowly missed an oncoming HGVBeloved headteacher Paula Kingdon was killed in the crash Image: Liverpool ECHOByJoe ThomasJoe Thomas:,  Oct | commentsA woman killed a former headteacher in a head-on crash after driving the wrong way down the M for five miles.Ann Marie Crookaposs Renault Clio hit the vehicle of Paula Kingdon moments after she had narrowly missed an oncoming HGV, reports the Liverpool Echo.The mum-of-two maintains she cannot explain what she was doing, but a judge today told her: The consequences of your actions were entirely foreseeable. Crook, , shocked drivers over the course of five miles at around .am on October ,  as she reached speeds of almost mph. Chris Hopkins, prosecuting, told Liverpool Crown Court that passing drivers used their lights and horns in a bid to get the attention of Crook.  Crook was seen driving westbound on the East Lancashire Road as she passed through Windle Island in St Helens. At the junction with Moorgate Road she entered the lane to turn right, only to continue straight and drive into oncoming traffic on the wrong side of the barrier separating the carriageways. Crook then turned down the M slip road, almost hitting a lorry head on before joining the motorway and driving at traffic heading in the opposite direction. The court heard the vehicle in front of Ms Kingdonaposs Honda Jazz swerved to get out of Crookaposs way, leaving the -year-old with no opportunity to avoid a crash. Shortly before the crash, one witness said: He could see her hands on the steering wheel. She was looking forward and appeared to be driving in a determined manner. Mr Hopkins said Crookaposs intentions remained unclear, but added: All of the evidence indicates this was a deliberate act and the only sensible conclusion that can be drawn is that the defendant was trying to harm herself.  Ms Kingdon and Crook both had to be cut out of their vehicles and taken to Aintree Hospital. Crook, of Cheviot Avenue in St Helens, spent time in a critical condition but survived. When interviewed by police, Crook said she had no recollection of the incident and suggested she had taken a wrong turn and panicked. Mr Hopkins said: The fact that that explanation is maintained by the defendant is something which has caused great distress to family members of the victim. The court heard Crook could offer no reason for a collection of photographs of motorway junctions, bridges and crash scenes that were recovered from her mobile phone. Mr Hopkins read a powerful statement on behalf of Stephen Sharples, the brother of Ms Kingdon. He detailed the compassion his sister displayed and the positive impact she had on so many lives through her work in education.  Ms Kingdon was from Merseyside but lived in Sheffield and had been the headteacher of Westfield Infants School, near Chesterfield, in Derbyshire. She was killed while she was driving home after visiting her Kirkby-based father-in-law, who she helped care for several days a week, and after having seen Liverpool FC play. Mr Sharples said: After a le time of devoting herself to others, Paula deserved the chance to enjoy her retirement... it is heartbreaking to me that Paula had this opportunity for a new chapter in her le taken away by the senseless actions of this stranger. Sarah Grfin, defending, said her client had previously been a woman of positive good character who had worked all her le, who is clearly dedicated to her children and is someone who could regularly be found helping family, friends and neighbours. Ms Grfin said Crook had not driven since the crash, and planned to never drive again.Judge Garrett Byrne addressed Ms Kingdonaposs family as he told the court: No sentence can restore Paula and no sentence can possibly compensate for her loss.The judge told Crook: The manner of your driving was such that it is dficult to think of a more serious case.He said: In my view the collision can be properly characterised as a deliberate act. You must have realised at the time that your driving was bound to cause someone at least serious harm,not their death. A letter written to Judge Byrne by Crook ended with her claiming she had no explanation for her actions. Highlighting the evidence that Crook made no attempt to avoid a crash, he concluded it was not a case of taking a wrong turn and then panicking, it was a deliberate course of conduct. The judge added that,it had been Crookaposs intention to harm herself, it was a profoundly selfish one because you were prepared to injure or kill others in achieving that goal. Crook admitted one count of causing death by dangerous driving. She was sentenced to four years and eight months and disqualied from driving for three years after her release. title: woman finds brutal note left
story: :root Woman finds brutal note left on parked car - and everyones finding it funnyMany people seemed to presume the note was a joke, with one person commenting: “There’s a Jesus take the wheel joke in this somewhere”An image of the note was shared online with the caption: “I shouldn’t laugh, but I’m going to…” Image: r CasualUKByAlice Peacock:,  Oct | comments A woman ed to her car to discover a brutal note left on the windscreen taking aim at her Christian bumper sticker to the amusement of social media users.Just above the note is a bumper sticker that reads “Jesus disciple”. The note, which read “PRETTY SURE JESUS WOULDN’T PARK LIKE A B******” was placed under the windscreen wipers on the rear window of a silver Mitsubishi. The image was shared online with the caption: “I shouldn’t laugh, but I’m going to…”A photo of the note was shared on Reddit and Instagram where many people presumed it to be a joke and found it hilarious.Many people seemed to presume the note was a joke, with one person commenting: “There’s a Jesus take the wheel joke in this somewhere”. Another pointed out: “Jesus has never driven a car before so he might actually park like that”. And another Reddit user cheekily said: “The Church of England wants a word”.It comes just days after a pair of furious sistersvoiced their angerat having notes stuck to their windscreens with glue and silicone after parking on a residential street.Ellie Newman, , and sister Jordana Timeyin, , park their matching Range Rover Velars on a street close to where they work in Manchester - but said they were shocked by the criminal damage. The sisters, who both work at nearby Loan Agency Bridgewater Acceptances, say their cars have repeatedly been targeted. On Thursday Ellie claims she discovered a note stuck with silicone to the windscreen of her black Range Rover after she finished work. The note in black felt tip pen read: Please stop using this street as a car park. Residents are coming home from work shopping and can not park on their own street!! But Ellie said she and sister Jordana are perfectly within their rights to park there, as they both pay tax. She said: There are no yellow lines. We work in the area and this is what we pay road tax for. Our offices have been there  years. This has happened about four times. We have had our car scratched and around four notes left, stuck on with super glue, gaffer tape and now silicone. This is criminal damage.  According to the official RAC parking guide: It is perfectly legal to park outside someone’s house, unless the vehicle is blocking a driveway or a wheel is over a dropped kerb. Other situations in which parking isn’t permitted include streets governed by residents’ parking permits or any of the restrictions outlined above, i.e. double yellow lines. Ellie says she has logged the incident to the police online. story: :root Woman nearly loses hand from  widow spider bite and now shes scared to sleep in bedWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGES - Morgan Curran, , says she initially thought the spider bite was a harmless bug bite and didnt seek medical help until it ballooned into an infection that required surgeryMorgan Curran, , shrugged off the spider bite as a harmless bug bite. Image: Kennedy News and MediaByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA carer who almost lost her hand to a  widow spider bite while she was in bed has been left so terried she sleeps on the living room sofa. Morgan Curran, , says she initially thought the spider bite was a harmless bug bite. However, days later, her right hand swelled like a boxing glove. It started to throb and a £ coin-sized black spot erupted underneath the knuckle on her middle finger. Morganaposs GP told her to go to AE where worried docs hooked her up to an IV drip and monitored the festering wound closely. After being pumped full of antibiotics, she remained in hospital for five days and underwent two operations to scoop out the infected tissue.  Morgan, who still fears she may get attacked again, is urging anyone who gets bit by a spider to seek medical attention as soon as possible. Doctors told Morgan she could have diedshe had not been treated in time. Morgan, from Oxfordshire, said: Iaposm OK with gory stuff but when they took the dressing off and I saw it I felt sick to my stomach.  It was hard to imagine that was on and inside me. At its biggest, my hand was like a boxing glove. It was completely puffed up and I couldnapost straighten my fingers because of all of the swelling. The relief of having everything bad taken out was less painful than while all the infection and pressure was building up. Once it had been cut open and the pressure was released it wasnapost too bad, but I was on strong painkillers.  Luckily they were able to [operate] without needing a skin graft. Iaposve always been a bit nervous of spiders anyway but itaposs a proper fear now that it could happen again. I think I was bitten while I was asleep because when I came home from the hospital there was a spider under my windowsill that looked a bit aggressive.  Iaposm convinced that was the one that had me - it had the skull-type shape on its back. Even nowI see the tiniest spider it has to be gone before I can get into bed. If I see one that Iaposve lost in my room Iaposll come down and sleep on the sofa because itaposs just too scary to sleep in there.  Morgan woke up one morning in April  with an itchy hand, initially thinking the pinhead-sized lump was a regular bug bite and popped a couple of antihistamines. Over the next two days, the lump ballooned and turned black in the centre. When she initially went to the pharmacy she was told to go to AE but left it until the next day because she had a concert that night. At the concert Morganaposs hand continued to swell, she suffered an intense burning and throbbing pain and booked a GP appointment for the following day.  The doctor referred her to John Radclfe Hospital in Oxford and there they hooked her up to an antibiotic IV drip, soaked her hand in iodine baths and eventually performed surgery to scoop out the infected tissue. After five days in the hospital, she was discharged and changed the bandages daily until the wound healed. Morgan said: The doctor said it was full of infection and thatIaposd left it much longer I could have possibly lost my hand, got sepsis or worst-case scenario - I could have lost my le.Morgan is now urging anyone who gets bitten to get wounds checked out sooner rather than later. Morgan said: It took a very long time to heal. I went back to work after five weeks but there was still a small wound there. I have a constant numbness like pins and needles and when itaposs cold I get a dull pain there. If I knock it on something it hurts more thanI were to knock my other hand on something. I definitely wish Iaposd got it checked out sooner rather than later, it might not have been so serious. Morgan now checks her bed every night before she climbs between the sheets andshe canapost locate a spider sheaposs spotted she sleeps on the sofa. Morgan said: I check the bedding before I get into bed now. Every time I walk into the room I check the corners for anything. Some nights I canapost sleep in there so I go into the living room and sleep on the sofa. Itaposs usually because Iaposve seen a spider, tried to get it but itaposs fallen and I canapost find it. My advice to anyone who is bitten is to get it checked because the pain is unreal, and unbearable. Itaposs just not worth having the surgery, the pain and a constant numbness. title: worlds first black pro footballer
story: :root World’s first black pro footballer who gave wages to the needy inspires a generationArthur Wharton was regarded as the best goalie in Britain in his day and is now inspiring a new generation of stars, including England striker Marcus Rashford who campaigns on child food povertyArthur Wharton - the Worlds First Black Professional Footballer Image: Daily MirrorByJeremy Armstrong:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe exceptional ability of football pioneer Arthur Wharton thwarted numerous opponents, but he also made a dference behind the scenes. Arthur, who in the s became the world’s first black professional footballer, gave his wages to the needy. The sportsman, regarded as the best goalie in Britain in his day, is inspiring a new generation of stars, including England striker Marcus Rashford who campaigns on child food poverty. Shaun Campbell, a businessman who set up the Arthur Wharton Foundation, said: “Arthur was a remarkable man. “Andyou think of what Marcus is doing today, Arthur was doing the same more than  years ago.  “Back then he was thinking of the poor. He was a black champion in his community. All those years ago he played and gave his time and wages for others. “There is a certain irony that all these years later, Marcus Rashford is doing the same thing. “It is sad that we still have these cases of children in need.”  Fans loved Arthur’s athleticism and showmanship. He became a box office star when professional football was in its infancy. Arthur was born in Accra in the Gold Coastin West Africa in . His mum was descended from the Fante royal family, and his dad was born in the West Indies, the son of a wealthy Scottish trader.The UK began celebrating Black History Month, an idea first spawned in the United States and then also adopted by European countries including Ireland and the Netherlands, in October . Black History Month helps give context to modern le and the countryaposs history, while championing the experiences and celebrating the contributions of Black Britons here in the UK. The observation was first organised through the leadership of Ghanaian-born analyst Akyaaba Addai-Sebo. He served as a coordinator of special projects for the Greater London Council. Consequently, Akyaaba created a plan aiming to recognise the contributions of African, Asian and Caribbean people to the economic, cultural and political le in the UK. Arthur moved to England aged  in the early-s to train as a Methodist missionary. But he decided instead to become a full-time athlete – excelling in numerous sports. Arthur, based in Darlington in Co Durham, joined Darlington FC in . A year later he broke the -yard world record, finishing the race in exactly  seconds. The record stood for over  years. His athletics achievements have wowed none other than Jamaican star Usain Bolt.  The eight-time Olympic gold medal sprinter told Shaun: “Without Arthur, there would be no Usain Bolt.” Arthur became a pro footballer with Rotherham Town in . At Sheffield United in -, the keeper became the first player of mixed heritage to play in the top flight of English football. At the time, players at the club could earn about £ a week . There were also win bonuses, usually of up to  shillings. The average weekly wage of a working man was £. Arthur, whose career lasted until , also played for Preston North End and Stockport County. He was also a cycling champ, and a fine cricketer and rugby player. He is an inspiration to a host of today’s stars. Those who have sent a video message to the Arthur Wharton Foundation – which promotes equality and champions his le – include Bolt, Rashford, Les Ferdinand and Stevie Wonder. Many footballers had not heard of Arthur before the foundation was set up. Viv Anderson, who in  became the first black player to represent England in a full international, learned about him through an exhibition at the National Football Museum in . He said: “I didn’t know his story until then – and I was a black professional footballer.” Arthur died penniless aged  in . There is now a ft statue of him at the FA’s HQ in Burton, Staffs. And in  he was inducted into the English Football Hall of Fame. Man United star Rashford has a giant mural in his hometown – just like the one unveiled in Darlington for Arthur. With sporting prowess as well as a social conscience, Arthur’s exploits on and off the pitch mean his legacy will live on.
